title: Support TYPECHANGE records in status and adjust checkout accordingly
body:
Type changes of files are not handling quite the same in our status implementation as they are in core git. The discrepancy results in different status output but also results in errors while processing type changes in checkout.

This adds more robust typechange support into diff and status, and then fixes checkout's ability to deal with type changes.

It also adds rudimentary submodule support to checkout (not that the actual checkout is done, but at least there is no error and a placeholder directory will be created). It also fixes a checkout bug with setting the executable bit on files that are type changed to be executable.

This is all exercised by some new test data that contains every sort of type change and then a test that tries to checkout each one of a series of commits in order.

title: Diff submodule tests and fixes
body:
There are a couple of bugs in the submodule diff implementation from PR  #940.

This includes a test of the submodule diff code and then a number of fixes for issues that came up in developing the test.

title: Save the autotag configuration for remotes
body: As an extra goodie, avoid downloading tags from remotes that don't have a name.

title: Jv linux mode32
body:
Added new option MODE32 to build 32bit library when on 64bit system. 
It's a bit hacky, but is seems that CMake lacks support for doing such a build.

title: Jv build on windows doc
body: Added more-detailed section how to build on Windows

issue #876
issue #951
issue #733

title: Updates config upon moving and deletion of branches
body: I don't really know what happened with #919... It looks like I closed it by accident.... Meh.

title: WIP - Add git_config_store support when handling config files
body:
This is linked to libgit2/libgit2sharp#161 and libgit2/libgit2sharp#162.

The current code is currently in a very early/rough shape, but as always, I'm all for a little feedback if you have better ideas on how it should be done.

What I am aiming at is:
- Being able to specify a `GIT_CONFIG_STORE_XXX` when adding a file to a `git_config`
- Retrieving this information when getting a config value (this would be done by making the get methods return a `git_config_entry`, which contains the key, the value and the store of the config element)
- Being able to specify a config store when calling `git_config_delete` (should there be an overload that takes no config store?)
- Being able to specify a config store when calling `git_config_set_xxx` (should there be an overload that takes no config store?)
- Being able to specify a config store when calling `git_config_get_xxx` (the existing overload which takes no config store should keep looking in all config files based on the priority)

I already:
- Modified `git_config_add_file` and `git_config_add_file_ondisk` to get the config store information
- Modified `git_config_foreach` to send a `git_config_entry` in the callback

Current thoughts/interrogations that I have, and would love to hear your ideas:
- I think priority and config store are two different things. I tried playing with the idea of keeping only the config store notion, but I thought I didn't feel right
- Currently, it's possible to add several config files with the same priority. I'm not really willing to change that. However, this raises the question of "Can we have several config files with the same config store defined?" (if yes, would this mean returning EAMBIGUOUS in the get/set methods?) => sorry, this is not very clear... I really need to spend more time on the implications of this
- I currently have a `GIT_CONFIG_STORE_OTHER` (used in submodule.c for example). I'm still wondering if I need it.


I'm sure I'm missing other things yet. I will continue working on this and try to provide something consistent.

Thanks!

title: Index v5
body: I'll start with some refactoring to put the v2 semantics into a seperat file.

title: A real struct for indicating progress
body: `git_indexer_stats` is soon to get more and more things that have nothing to do with reporting progress. This PR introduces a new struct `git_progress`.

title: WIP - Unsymlinked
body:
This PR is something between a WIP and some R&D. It originates back to libgit2/libgit2sharp#196 and libgit2/libgit2sharp#201.

Curiously, it looks like the .Net tests pass on Mono, Windows x86 but fail on Windows amd64

This PR brings the C version of one of the .Net test in order to try to troubleshoot this at the libgit2 level.

title: [GSoC] RFC: pack objects
body:
Except for the limitations listed below it works similar to `git pack-objects --no-reuse-delta ...`

Limitations:

* `compute_write_order` not finished yet
* Not configurable yet (pack.packSizeLimit, pack.compression, pack.deltaCacheLimit, etc.)
* No splitting of packs (in case we hit packSizeLimit)
* No threading

title: WIP - Stash
body:
- `git_stash_save()`
  - GIT_STASH_KEEP_INDEX
  - GIT_STASH_INCLUDE_UNTRACKED
  - GIT_STASH_INCLUDE_IGNORED

 - `git_stash_foreach()`

title: [GSoC] RFC: SSH transport
body:
Very rough first version of the SSH transport.

Issues:

1. Currently, ssh netops ([netops.h](https://github.com/schu/libgit2/pull/new/gsoc-ssh-transport#diff-5)) have their own namespace. At the moment, I tend to change that towards something like we do for ssl, having a flag  which indicates what transport to use in the git netops functions. Opinions?

2. Obviously, there's too much redundant code. I'll refactor (moving more stuff into [transports/util](https://github.com/schu/libgit2/pull/new/gsoc-ssh-transport#diff-12)) as soon as there's a decision for 1.

3. This is based on #725 for setting an authentication callback.

4. Doesn't work on Windows yet.

title: Fix a bug where ignorecase wasn't applied to ignores
body:
There was a mistake in my previous submission for core.ignorecase support, where I was setting a flag just prior to calling a function which masked out the very bit I was trying to set! The result was that with ignorecase set, a .gitignore rule saying to ignore a.txt would not match A.txt. The file would show up as added, when it should actually be ignored.

This patch fixes the bug and adds a test case to verify correct operation and prevent future regression.

title: Win64 cleanups
body:
Okay, so I figured out why I was seeing test failures on Windows that no one else seems to be seeing...

I was testing with the 64-bit build on Windows 7 64-bit, but I have a 32-bit version of msysgit installed. This meant that libgit2 was not finding the `c:\Program Files (x86)\Git\etc\gitconfig` file. That meant that the tests thought that symlinks are supported on the platform. That meant that in the `git_checkout` tests, when there was symlink in the index, the diff code converted the apparent type change into a REMOVE / ADD pair, but there is a latent bug in `git_checkout` that an ADD is unexpected and results in a failure.

I will open a separate PR to deal with the typechange issues in diff, status, and checkout, because it is actually a much larger issue if we are going to really match core git.

This PR fixes a bunch of Win64 build warnings, cherry picks one of @csware's commits from #952 (to find msysgit via the registry), and implements the rest of the msysgit environment variable expansions, but in a slightly different manner than #952 just because I don't trust that we won't have to change them again in the future.

If we merge this PR, then #952 can focus just on dealing with supporting the XDG paths, which will probably make it easier to talk about...

title: Fix error hashing empty file.
body:
Pull Request around an issue when hashing an empty (0 byte) files in the working directory of a repository. This issue is hit when getting the status of a repository whose working directory includes an empty file. This includes a test covering this issue.

The hashing logic did not discern between not reading from a file because it was empty and the read function returning an error.

Appreciate any thoughts / comments on this

Thanks!

title: revwalk: fix off-by-one error
body: @carlosmn: could you have a look on  a7d42f3 and explain what's behind the apparently useless check? Thanks!

title: Include tag
body:
Behave more like git by trying to create as many tags as we can after a fetch.

The first commit overlaps with #954. Maybe `_clear` is a better name, though `git_buf_clear` doesn't free the memory; and this function doesn't actually free the object you're giving it, so... naming is hard.

I still need to add support for the `--tags` version (i.e., do force all tags).

Do you think that git_remote_save() should try to store the `remote.<name>.tagopt` setting to the one that's set?

title: New refspec code leaks memory
body:
This fixes a memory leak in the tests that I found in valgrind along with adding a new API so that other users can also free the memory of the refspec object.

I'm doing this as a pull request because I'm wondering if I'm just missing something about how users are supposed to handle `git_refspec` objects and thought maybe @carlosmn or someone would comment...

title: Deploy git_repository_set_head()
body:
- Use constants for well-known refs related names and namespaces
 - Enhance branch moving test coverage
 - Make reset rely on `git_repository_head()`
 - Deploy `git_repository_set_head()` usage

title: Make clear that git_odb_hashfile does not use filters
Make giterr_set_str() and giterr_set_oom() public APIs
body: There has been discussion for a while about making some set of the `giterr_set` type functions part of the public API for code that is implementing new backends to libgit2. (See issues #755 and #846.) This makes the `giterr_set_str()` and `giterr_set_oom()` functions public. Hopefully this will help binding authors and backend implementors integrate more smoothly with libgit2.

title: Pull code request
body: Pull code request

title: Tags: teach git_tag_list not to include the 'refs/tags/' prefix
body:
Since quite a while now, `git_branch_foreach` has learnt to list branches
without the `refs/heads/` or `refs/remotes/` prefixes.
This patch teaches `git_tag_list` to do the same for listing tags (i.e. omit the leading `refs/tags/`)

title: git_repository_hashfile: Only close file handle if we have a valid one
body: Otherwise this throws an exception on MFC based systems.

title: checkout: add notification callback for skipped files
body:
Add an optional `skipped_notify_cb` callback to the `git_checkout_opts ` to notify the consumer of files that haven't be checked out because a modified version of them exist in the working directory. 

When provided, this callback will be invoked when the flag GIT_CHECKOUT_OVERWRITE_MODIFIED isn't part of the checkout strategy.

title: Create a diff patch object as a replacement for iterators
body:
This is a proposed alternative to the `git_diff_iterator` APIs that would make the deltas in a diff addressable by index and add a `git_diff_patch` object that encapsulates all the text diffs for a given delta. The hunks and lines in the patch could also then be accessed by index.

This would replace the iterator API with something much simpler - just use an int to walk through a diff. It would still coexist with the `git_diff_foreach` API since that can be more memory efficient.

title: Diff: Show submodule diff
body:
Iterating a diff between two trees used to return `GIT_ENOTFOUND`, if it contained a submodule. This is because it tries to load the submodule commit from the superproject odb.

Also, submodule changes between index/worktree and HEAD were not reported at all.

This PR addresses both of those issues and so adds support to output the submodule differences like core git does:
```
diff --git a/libgit2 b/libgit2
--- a/libgit2
+++ b/libgit2
@@ -1 +1 @@
-Subproject commit 411cb017c21e0490ed1c6438c7d5fa1b4ee9f63f
+Subproject commit 411cb017c21e0490ed1c6438c7d5fa1b4ee9f63f-dirty
```

title: Support for the core.ignorecase flag
body:
This pull request adds support for `core.ignorecase` to libgit2. When appropriate, we use strcasecmp to compare strings instead of strcmp.

When `core.ignorecase` is on, the index object for the repository stores entries in strcasecmp order. This means that index iterators yield results in strcasecmp order as well.

When `core.ignorecase` is on, the workdir iterator returns strcasecmp-ordered results, too.

The tree iterator (representing committed data) always returns data sorted with strcmp. When merge joining results from two iterators that do not sort their output in the same way, the case-sensitive iterator has its results spooled into memory and then sorted before the merge join can occur, using an iterator type called `spoolandsort`. This is a performance penalty, of course.

When we write out the index, and the data stored in the index is in strcasecmp order, we make sure to re-sort it to strcmp order on the way out to disk.

Do people think this approach is the way to go, or are there other opinions about how to attack the problem? Is there anything obvious or non-obvious that I've missed?

title: Topic/is valid name
body: introduce `git_reference_is_valid_name()`

title: refs: prevent locked refs from being enumerated
body: Fix #936

title: Fix MSVC compilation warnings
body:
```
2>src\repository.c(1425): warning C4244: '=' : conversion from 'git_off_t' to 'int', possible loss of data
2>src\repository.c(1435): warning C4244: 'function' : conversion from 'git_off_t' to 'size_t', possible loss of data
```

title: pack: iterate objects in offset order
body: Compute the ordering on demand and persist until the index is freed.

title: ODB: re-load packfiles on failed lookup
body:
The old method was avoiding re-loading of packfiles by watching the mtime of the
pack directory. This causes the ODB to become stale if the directory and packfile
are written within the same clock millisecond, as when cloning a fairly small
repo.

This method tries to find the object in the cached packs, and forces a refresh when
that fails. This will cause extra stat'ing on a miss, but speeds up the success
case and avoids this race condition.

title: Fix error text s/buffer too long/buffer too short/
body: Assuming this error message was not meant as a funny consolation for the user.

title: refspec: No remote tracking ref from a fetchspec-less remote
Fix problems in diff iterator record chaining
body: There is a bug in building the linked list of line records in the diff iterator and also an off by one element error in the hunk counts.  This fixes both of these, adds some test data with more complex sets of hunk and line diffs to exercise this code better.

title: odb_pack: try lookup before refreshing packs
body:
This reduces the rate of syscalls for the common case of sequences of
object reads from the same pack.

Best of 5 timings for `libgit2_clar` before this patch:

    real    0m5.375s
    user    0m0.392s
    sys     0m3.564s

After applying this patch:

    real    0m5.285s
    user    0m0.356s
    sys     0m3.544s

0.6% improvement in system time.
9.2% improvement in user time.
1.7% improvement in elapsed time.

Confirmed a 0.6% reduction in number of system calls with `strace`.

Expect greater improvement for graph-traversal with large packs.

title: Add git_repository_hashfile to hash with filters
body:
The existing `git_odb_hashfile` does not apply text filtering rules because it doesn't have a repository context to evaluate the correct rules to apply.  This adds a new hashfile function that will apply repository-specific filters (based on config, attributes, and filename) before calculating the hash.

The new function looks like:

```c
GIT_EXTERN(int) git_repository_hashfile(
    git_oid *out,
    git_repository *repo,
    const char *path,
    git_otype type,
    const char *as_path);
```

This was discussed in issue #862 and this is a response to that issue.

Comments welcome!

title: cache: fix race condition
Fix a hang in git_odb__hashfd
body:
If the size of a file that is being hashed by `git_odb__hashfd` decreases after the size of the file is fetched by a stat call, but before the file is opened for read by the caller, then `git_odb__hashfd` will spin forever.

`read()` starts returning zero for the number of bytes read once EOF is reached, but size is still > 0, so the loop never terminates.

With this patch, we treat a 0 byte read as EOF and complete the hash even though we know it must be wrong (because the object header has the wrong size in it).

For the purposes of computing status, having a "wrong" hash is just fine -- that just means the object ID comparison will fail and the item will count as modified. The code path for blob creation, where we want stronger guarantees, doesn't (and won't ever) go through `git_odb__hashfd`.

I would be interested to know whether people think doing it this way is better or worse than changing the signature to not take in a size, and having `git_odb__hashfd` call fstat on the file descriptor to get the size. That would prevent the problem by giving no ability to the caller to pass in a file size captured before the fd was opened for read. There would presumably be a perf penalty from the extra stat.

title: git_mergebase: Constness-Fix for consistency
body:
Simply turns `git_mergebase()`'s `git_oid*` parameters into `const git_od*` ones.

Just a little inconsistency I stumbled upon when playing around with mergebases.
